text: in the spring of 1982 I was a was a
sophomore at Harvard and a rumor started
to bubble through the physics department
that the Morris lobe lecture this
honorary series of lectures that had
been going on since the 1950s would be
given by Stephen Hawking and I went to
the lecture and when I entered that room
the energy the pulse was palpable every
seat was taken there were students in
the aisles on the floor everybody just
trying to get packed in to this lecture
it was so electric now in those days
professor Hawking didn't use a computer
synthesizer for speech instead he would
murmur a low murmur and he had a trained
graduate student or postdoc I would
think who kept his ear very close to
professor Hawking and would then repeat
what professor Hawking said in a more
audible level now this two-step process
for me had the advantage that it slowed
things down so I could kind of have a
chance of understanding what was going
on but even so most of the material was
over my head but it really hardly
mattered because it was so clear that
professor Hawking was taking us on this
fantastic mathematical Odyssey through
the Big Bang black holes this tremendous
soaring flight from one end of the
cosmos to the other
I left that lecture pumped I left the
Science Center went across the campus
went into Harvard Yard and I just wanted
to jump up on a bench and say Einstein
Hawking general relativity through his
mathematics more than any other member
of our species professor Hawking has
traveled closest
to the edge of time thank you very much
[Applause]
[Music]
